text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: OLIVER EVANS, HOBSON

Present Address: 835 RAFT ST., Regina

Pioneer Address: Carwood & Grenfell

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1889

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? They were close homesteads.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? Not many.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once a week.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Some evenings.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Yes.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? In the evenings.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Always.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Always, just like all our big family.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Tea or cake or sandwiches.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? All went.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Not too much, once in a while.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Dances in homes all winter.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Used to see house a turn once a month. Then there then start all over again.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE,

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?

(That is, was the term "make pot luck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what their refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to lock after the place?

6. Did you ever have "seats" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "seats" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in times? Describe.

There those more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc. if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

Green held in School

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

I left school a gain the spring.
Then went in the winter

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

Put in the Stable Some way.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Were & 500 & King Pedro.

Was there card playing for a prize? No

What dances were popular?

Square Dances & Waltzing
Polkas & Step & Country

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

None

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

None
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school children's plays, dramas, etc.)

If you have not described these on the school questionnaires, give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district?

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 9), and/or did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any discrepancy between dancing and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? 
Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc. that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? 
Brown Hill Trot Ball Club.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? 
Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? 
When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formality, or "awakening," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visits often treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? 
Describe what you remember about chivalries, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular in visiting or social life before noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? 
Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Club in your community? 
Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?
When was it organized?
Approximately how many women belonged to it?
Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or has centered in the town or village and included the surrounding communities. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Collections & Beggars

or Suffered Only.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides? Minister Comics

Rev. T. G. Beal

What were the slides about?

Tung One Like a Man with a Wood Leg Taking a Mustard Bath For a Bad Cold & So

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

Foot Ball

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

Skipping & Swings
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1911, giving the name of each, its purpose, who belonged (name of people), whether it was a religious, charitable, or social club, etc.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

21. What games did boys play in summer? (Skipping rope, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)

CHILDREN'S GAMES

22. What games did girls play in summer? (Skipping rope, play house, etc.)
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   Fox & Hounds & Skating

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   Do Questions & Name the article

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   Children at School

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   July 1903

26. Who organized it?  
   Don't Know

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   Yes

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   Don't Know

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?  
   No

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   Ball game & Races & Swimming

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   Every one took a Big Basket - it was all Seated out - served up at long tables

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   Milk & Lemonade for the Kids & Tea & Coffee

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   Around 1 PM
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.

What games were played indoors in winter, such as "Happy Family," "Mushers," or others? Did the children play these games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, spheres, or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICTURES AND SPORTS

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

Give year and month, if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Stanley school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Swimming Races &c.
Catching the Guinea Pig.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Every one women & women &
Kids all took Part.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Foot Ball

What year? How long did it continue?
Long after 1910

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Used to Skate on the Closer
The Pipe stone
13. Describe the key features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Catching the quarry pos.

14. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you know of in the early days, such as the big community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in methods attending, entertainers, food and drinks, games, etc.

15. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first year? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

16. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, boys, young people).

One woman's only game? Playing kids all could play.

17. For what game was the first team organized in your community?

Foot Ball

18. How did it get started?

Long after 9/29/1910

19. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1910. Giving date of organization, how it started, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

20. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

United To Scholar On The Mohican

The Pupa Clan
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?  
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?  
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?  

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).  
   May 24th

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?  
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?  
   Block Beauty  
   The life of Stone

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library?  
   When was it begun?  
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?  
   No
40. When did an annual sports day become established in your community?  
   Did it grow out of earlier community plans?  
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?  
   What was the sports day usually called (what month, or any special day) such 
   as May 24th or July 4th?

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known 
   clubs, teams, or other associations? (Give names and dates.)

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the 
   titles, authors, and publishers if possible.) If not, tell me exactly what you 
   brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

READING

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?  
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy any books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "traveling library" books in your community or school? 
   Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library?  
   When was it begun?  
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to 
   read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading 
   material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?  
   When was it started?  
   Who started it?  
   Is it still in existence?  
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   The Winnipeg Paper & later The Grenfell Sun which I still take.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   - Who started it?
   - In what year was it established?
   - If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contains, how many people used it, how it was kept, who did the cataloging, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? (List newspapers and magazines)

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you changed or added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lucy Aberdeen packages of reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started? How long did it continue?

Who started it?

How many were in it?

Who was bandmaster?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57a. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, please if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your house entertainment in early years in the Western Deseret?

In the community? (were there musical concerts, parties, etc.) Describe.

60. Were some of the favorite songs in the home?

Any faith used to sing such songs?

In the community?

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community?

Who started it?

How many were in it?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where,

If members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Better in the old days at Portage

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? No

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

I went on the Railway when a young man of about 14 years as an Engineer Trainee. Mentioned after 10 years in 1951.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? No

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

I do some carpenter work, have a work shop, 12x20, & do cement work jobs if people want me to.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

May state that Sir Richard Coke started in government in Brown Hill Community & was later the Governor of Sask & B.C., also Mr. Paterson who was Premier of Sask. & now the Governor of Sask. Come from Gunfell Raised There.
64. Has anyone from your community been well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music so important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. To you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you began, and any interesting events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

[Handwritten note:]
General State That Sir Richard Luke

Started in Government in 1800 & 1812,
& was Lord Lieutenant of Premier of Sark
also on Poltirn Luke was Premier of Sark
& then Sir George & Sark came from
& Sir Gurjell raised there
Oxford

No. 613 S
